topics.title: Opening philosophy: progress, optimism, dissatisfaction
topics.summary: Tobi shares his core energy source—dissatisfaction with the status quo—and argues that progress is the antidote to “future dystopia” narratives. He critiques business aesthetics (suits, pessimism, metric-theater) and elevates fun and delight as powerful forces.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Tobi and frames the conversation around first principles thinking and maximizing human potential. He tees up the discussion style and recurring themes heard from Shopify leaders.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sinch (RCS messaging) and Liveblocks (collaboration features platform).

topics.title: The 'Tobi tornado' and rapid change management
topics.summary: Tobi defines the “Tobi tornado” as compressing conflict, real talk, and change into a short window—sometimes stopping projects and rebooting with the same team as “founders” of the next version. He explains why acting quickly is fairer than letting teams grind on the wrong thing.

topics.title: Direct feedback as a tool for potential
topics.summary: Tobi explains his belief that no one is near their maximum potential and that high standards plus direct feedback help people surpass what they thought possible. He connects this to Shopify’s mission: making entrepreneurs more successful and ambitious over time.

topics.title: Learning, school incentives, and curiosity preservation
topics.summary: They discuss how schooling can “overfit” to grades and suppress curiosity, contrasting fixed-time/variable-outcome learning with real skill development. Tobi suggests optimizing children’s education for sustained curiosity rather than benchmark performance.

topics.title: Operating without OKRs: metrics, taste, and Goodhart’s law
topics.summary: Tobi explains why Shopify avoids OKRs/KPIs as goals (Goodhart’s law) while remaining deeply data-informed with sophisticated instrumentation. He argues most product value is unquantifiable (taste, quality, brand pride) and that fun/delight can be leading indicators of future metric gains.

topics.title: First principles and futurism: designing for the world ahead
topics.summary: Prompted by Glen Coates’ quote, Tobi describes deriving solutions from current atomic building blocks rather than copying path-dependent incumbents. He frames his motivation as dissatisfaction with the present and a duty to build toward progress.

topics.title: Examples of first principles: Shopify’s origin and search rebuilds
topics.summary: Tobi uses Shopify’s founding as an example: optimize for new internet-native entrepreneurs rather than legacy retail complexity, which later proved strong for enterprise too. He also mentions revisiting search as models enable better retrieval and more delightful experiences.

topics.title: Re-running decisions like code: remote-work pivot
topics.summary: Tobi describes decision-making as re-running a function over updated assumptions; when a foundational boolean flips (COVID restrictions), the whole decision tree can land somewhere new. He explains why Shopify chose remote-first and why building remote culture is harder but strategically superior.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Loom (async video messaging to reduce meetings and improve alignment).

topics.title: Why Tobi still codes: craft, closeness to the metal
topics.summary: Tobi explains coding as his “happy place,” rooted in early apprenticeship and love of the craft, and as a way to sanity-check ideas and find insights in data. Lenny connects this to first principles leadership: staying close to implementation details rather than operating purely at the abstraction layer.

topics.title: Engineering strategy decisions: monorepo, sunk costs, changing minds
topics.summary: Tobi argues first principles requires understanding atomic building blocks (computers/software) and resisting sunk-cost fallacy. He describes being involved in consequential technical strategy (e.g., monorepo) and holding strong opinions that change quickly when evidence improves.
